title: SAR Requirements
name: Hover over the compound to learn about the SAR Characteristics

compoundHotspots.name: Ring A
compoundHotspots.text: Pi-Pi stacking with BZR

compoundHotspots.name: Ring B
compoundHotspots.text: H-bond acceptor (O, N, S) or N-heterocycle required. 1,2 annelation (N-heterocycle) increases affinity for BZR

compoundHotspots.name: N1
compoundHotspots.text: Methyl group preferred; bulky group decreases activity because it prevents binding to BZR

compoundHotspots.name: C7
compoundHotspots.text: EWG increases activity

compoundHotspots.name: Ring C
compoundHotspots.text: Hydrophobic interaction with BZR

compoundHotspots.name: C2
compoundHotspots.text: F or Cl substitution reduces aromatic hydroxylation and improves half-life

compoundHotspots.name: C3
compoundHotspots.text: OH group eliminates first pass metabolism as the hydroxyl acts as a “handle” for conjugation.

compoundHotspots.name: C4
compoundHotspots.text: steric repulsion occurs with para substituent

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity?
explanation: Addition of a bulky group at N1 prevents binding to the BZR; methyl group is preferred

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity?
explanation: Addition of Cl to position 2 reduces aromatic hydroxylation (phase one P450 metabolism) and increases half-life

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 compounds would be the best benzodiazepine for use as a hypnotic?
explanation: It already has the hydroxyl handle (position 3) so it is quickly metabolized to an inactive metabolite by conjugation; thus it has a short elimination half-life, which is ideal for hypnotics

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 compounds would be the best benzodiazepine for use as an anxiolytic?
explanation: The compound is slowly absorbed because it has a carboxylic acid that must be cleaved first (like a prodrug) and it is metabolized to an active metabolite; thus it has a long elimination half-life (40-50 hr), which is ideal for anxiolytics

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Predict Metabolite Activity
question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compounds (2, 3) and Conjugated Products

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Predict Metabolite Activity
question: Would compound 1 (temazepam) be an ideal hypnotic or anxiolytic? Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for compound 2

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Predict Metabolite Activity
question: Would compound 1 (triazolam) be an ideal hypnotic or anxiolytic? Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compounds (2, 3) and Conjugated Products

disubstitution required for activity

colorLocationAssociations.description: Barbiturates can undergo enol-keto tautomerization, which gives them near neutral pkas (7.4). Less than 50% gets ionized, so good balance of solubility and CNS penetration.
Without any substitution at position 5, the acidic hydrogen gets deprotonated. Resonance stabilization leads to lower pka (4) and 99% ionization occurs, so unable to penetrate the CNS.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity?
explanation: Changing C=S to C=O decreases lipophilicity and onset of action

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity?
explanation: 5,5- disubstitution needed for activity in order for CNS penetration

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 compounds would be a CNS active barbiturate?
explanation: 5,5- disubstitution and weak acid (N1 or N3 must be unsubstituted) are required for activity in order for CNS penetration

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Trissa is 30-year old female suffering from anxiety and insomnia. What one compound would be best to treat both her anxiety and insomnia?
explanation: Benzodiazepine (Compound 2)

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Sakiya is 24-year old female suffering from anxiety and insomnia. Sakiya’s boyfriend takes one of these hypnotics for insomnia and it helps keep him asleep with no hangover effects in the morning. LM decides to take one of his pills, but in the morning she is still sleepy. Which of these compounds did she take and why is she still experiencing effects in the morning?
explanation: Zolpidem (Compound 1); women metabolize slower

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Lance is 27-year old female suffering from anxiety and insomnia. Unfortunately, Lance has had abuse disorders in the past. Which of these compounds would be safest to use to treat her insomnia?
explanation: Ramelteon (Compound 3); not a scheduled drug

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Henry is 45-year old male who has recently been suffering from  what is believed to be absence seizures. Which compound should he be prescribed?
explanation: Ethosuximide (Compound 2); best used for absence seizures

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Amir is 48-year old male who has recently been suffering from what is believed to be absence seizures. Unfortunately, ethosuximide was not effective, and it is decided that Amir needs a medication for partial seizures instead. Amir also is taking several other medications. Which compound should he take?
explanation: : Lamotrigine (Compound 3); not metabolized by CYP and does not induce CYP, which could interfere with other medications

colorLocationAssociations.description: Basic nitrogen: protonated at physiological pH; pKa 8.7−9.8
Electron-withdrawing group: para or meta substitution enhances binding affinity for SERT; while Ortho substitution (except CF3) enhances binding affinity for NET and results in NRI
Phenoxy: distinguishes antidepressant and antihistamine activity (derived from diphenhydramine).
Basic nitrogen: protonated at physiological pH; pKa 8.7−9.8
Electron-withdrawing group: para or meta substitution enhances binding affinity for SERT; while Ortho substitution (except CF3) enhances binding affinity for NET and results in NRI
Phenoxy: distinguishes antidepressant and antihistamine activity (derived from diphenhydramine).
Basic nitrogen: protonated at physiological pH; pKa 9.5
Chlorine: enhances SERT selectivity
Basic nitrogen: protonated at physiological pH; pKa 9.5
Chlorine: enhances SERT selectivity

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
explanation: The presence of an EWG (CF3) increases SERT activity of phenoxyphenylalkyl amines

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
explanation: The presence of the phenoxy (O directly attached to phenyl ring) distinguishes SRIs from diphenhydramine

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
explanation: The S isomer of fluoxetine is 100x more selective for SERT

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
explanation: Ortho EWG substitution results in NRI and decreases SERT affinity

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants has major side effects as GI upset and sexual dysfunction?
explanation: Paroxetine is an SRI, which commonly shows these adverse events

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is most selective for SERT?
explanation: Sertraline is an SRI, which is selective for SERT. Compound 1 is an NRI and compound 2 is a secondary amine TCA, which is more selective for NET.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Predict Metabolite Activity
question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compounds (1, 3)

colorLocationAssociations.description: Serotonin and Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors do not have any Structure Activity Requirements but these are some helpful structures to be familiar with.
Serotonin and Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors do not have any Structure Activity Requirements but these are some helpful structures to be familiar with.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is active at both SERT and NET?
explanation: Duloxetine is an SNRI, which is active at SERT and NET. Compound 1 is SRI and Compound 3 is bupropion, which weakly blocks DAT and NET

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is considered activating and may raise blood pressure?
explanation: Venlafaxine is an SNRI, which is known to be activating

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: Alfred Smith is 80-year old male suffering from depression. He is currently taking paroxetine, but it is not helping. What one compound would you recommend he try next?
explanation: Compound 1 is an SRI, which he was currently taking and not helping. Compound 2 is a tertiary amine TCA, which acts as a SNRI and would be helpful, but leads to adverse effects such as sedation and hypotension so not recommended in elderly. Compound 3 (venlafaxine) is best choice as it is SNRI, with few adverse effects.

colorLocationAssociations.description: Linker of 3 carbons between tricyclic ring system and basic nitrogen. Branching from linker decreases binding affinity for SERT and NET. Unsaturation of linker is tolerated.
R→ CH3, tertiary amine imparts selectivity for SERT
R’→ Cl or CN (EWG) enhances binding affinity for SERT

colorLocationAssociations.location: Y→ can be C or N
colorLocationAssociations.description: Y→ can be C or N
Conformationally rigid [6.7.6]-fused ring system - 7 membered ring in the middle is not coplanar; results in twisted shape
Linker of 3 carbons between tricyclic ring system and basic nitrogen. Branching from linker decreases binding affinity for SERT and NET. Unsaturation of linker is tolerated.
R→ H, secondary amine imparts selectivity for NET
R’→ no substitution decreases SERT preference

colorLocationAssociations.location: Y→ can be C or N

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
explanation: Tertiary→ Secondary amine decreases binding affinity for SERT

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Would the following change to the compound increase, decrease, or have no effect upon activity at SERT?
explanation: Presence of EWG (Cl) enhances binding affinity for SERT

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants is active at both SERT and NET?
explanation: Compound 2, amitriptyline is a tertiary TCA, which is active at SERT and NET. Compound 1 is SRI and Compound 3 is a secondary TCA, only active at NET

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants causes significant dry mouth, constipation, and sedation?
explanation: Compound 1, clomipramine is a tertiary TCA, which is can bind to muscarinic and histamine receptors resulting in off target adverse effects. Compound 2 is a SRI and does not cause these adverse effects. Compound 3 is a mirtazepine and while it can cause sedation, it does not display anticholinergic effects such as dry mouth and constipation.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Predict Metabolite Activity
question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compound products. Would amitriptyline be an ideal antidepressant for the elderly?
explanation: Aamitriptyline causes anticholinergic effects, therefore it is not an ideal antidepressant for the elderly.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Predict Metabolite Activity
question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compound products
explanation: No explanation for this item.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Predict Metabolite Activity
question: Predict whether the metabolites will be active or inactive for the compound product. Is nortriptyline considered an SNRI or NRI?
explanation: Nortriptyline is a secondary TCA so it is more selective for NET.

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants can also be used for smoking cessation?
explanation: Bupropion

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants causes sedation by blocking histamine receptors?
explanation: Mirtazepine

title: Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of these 3 antidepressants can result in a hepatotoxic metabolite?
explanation: Metabolism of Trazodone

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: Mary Sue is 25-year old male suffering from depression. She complains of feeling tired and gaining weight with her last course of antidepressants. Which compound would you recommend her to try?
explanation: Compound 1 (trazodone) can cause sedation. Compound 2 (amitriptyline) can cause weight gain. Compound 3 (bupropion) would be a good alternative for this patient to prevent unwanted adverse effects.

title: Practice Problem
name: Mechanism of Action
question: Which compound below interferes with peptide cross-linking?
explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) Binds directly to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminal to prevent peptide cross-linking.

title: Practice Problem
name: Mechanism of Action
question: Which compound below inhibits the conversion of UDP-NAG→ UDP-NAM?
explanation: Fosfomycin (Compound 2) Results in irreversible alkylation of the active cysteine on MurA.

title: Practice Problem
name: Mechanism of Action
question: Which compound below inhibits Ala racemase & D-Ala ligase?
explanation: Cycloserine (Compound 3) Prevents conversion of L-Ala→ D-Ala and the joining of D-Ala & D-Ala.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Mechanism of Action
question: Which compound below inhibits pyrophosphatase?
explanation: Bacitracin (Compound 1) Inhibits the recycling of bactoprene molecule.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: GT is diagnosed with C. difficile. Which oral antibiotic would be best to treat his infection?
explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) is not orally absorbed, so it will stay in the gut to treat the infection in the large intestine

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: SM is diagnosed with a UTI infection. Which compound would be best to treat his infection and has few side effects?
explanation: Fosfomycin (Compound 2) is indicated for urinary tract infections, and is especially active against E. Coli

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: GT has a history of psychosis. Which antibiotic below is best avoided in this patient?
explanation: Cycloserine (Compound 1) acts as a partial agonist at the NMDA receptor can result in dose-dependent neurologic and psychiatric disturbances.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: BK has kidney dysfunction. Which 2 antibiotics below have side effects that would be harmful to this patient?
explanation: Bacitracin (Compound 1) and vancomycin (Compound 3) can both result in nephrotoxicity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: AM’s bacterial infection is not responding to treatment. The bacteria in her body have become resistant to the antibiotic by producing D-Ala-D-Lac. Which of the antibiotics was she taking?
explanation: Vancomycin (Compound 3) normally binds to D-Ala-D-Ala of the pentapeptide tail, but with this change to D-Ala-D-Lac, it can no longer bind.

title: SAR Requirements
name: Penicillin: Hover over compound to view areas.

compoundHotspots.name: β-Lactam Ring
compoundHotspots.text: β-Lactam Ring & Fused Bicyclic System: Creates a strained system (but less strain than the penicillins, so less reactive)

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a nitrogen

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site

compoundHotspots.name: Position 3
compoundHotspots.text: Any change will lower activity

compoundHotspots.name: Position 4
compoundHotspots.text: Sulfur is usual, but not essential

compoundHotspots.name: Position 5
compoundHotspots.text: No substitutions allowed; cis stereochemistry with hydrogens at position 5 & 6 is essential

compoundHotspots.name: R Group
compoundHotspots.text: EWG: increases the acid stability of the compound. Bulky group: directly attached to the amide will make the compound more B-lactamase resistant. Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carbonyl

title: SAR Requirements
name: Cephalosporin: Hover over compound to view areas.

compoundHotspots.name: β-Lactam Ring
compoundHotspots.text: β-Lactam Ring & Fused Bicyclic System: Creates a strained system.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a nitrogen

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carboxylic acid for activity; binds to charged nitrogen of a lysine residue in the binding site

compoundHotspots.name: Position 3
compoundHotspots.text: R2 Group: Non-metabolized group: increases oral activity & acid stability. MTT group: extended spectrum, longer-half life, higher potency. Pyrimidine ring (positive charge): forms a zwitterion & increases solubility. 1,3 thiazole ring: Anti-MRSA activity

compoundHotspots.name: Position 5
compoundHotspots.text: Sulfur is usual, but not essential

compoundHotspots.name: Position 6
compoundHotspots.text: No substitutions allowed

compoundHotspots.name: R1 Group
compoundHotspots.text: EWG: increases the acid stability of the compound. Bulky group: directly attached to the amide will make the compound more B-lactamase resistant. Polar group: broadens the spectrum as this allows the compound to pass through the porins of gram negative bacteria. Oxime: increases B-lactamase resistance.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: R3 group: Addition of OCH3 (7-alpha-methoxy) increases B-lactamase resistance

compoundHotspots.name: Position 8
compoundHotspots.text: Must be a carbonyl

explanation: No explanation provided.

question: Which addition to amide side chain (R) makes penicillins more acid stable?
explanation: No explanation provided.

name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: Which addition to amide side chain (R) makes penicillins less susceptible to B-lactamases?
explanation: No explanation provided.

title: SAR Practice Problem

question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: Sulfate group essential for activity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: Carboxylic acid essential for activity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound(s) are acid stable and can be taken orally?
explanation: Both compound 1 (cefaclor) & compound 2 (cefdinir) contain non-metabolizable groups at position 3.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound(s) has increased β-lactamase resistance?
explanation: Both compound 1 (cefepime) and compound 2 (cefdinir) contains oxime group as R1

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound has increased β-lactamase resistance?
explanation: Compound 3 (cefotetan) Contains 7-alpha-methoxy group.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound is most active against staph infections?
explanation: Compound 2 (methicillin) contain non-metabolizable groups at position.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound shows the highest oral bioavailability?
explanation: Compound 1 (amoxicillin) contains polar R group and does not form a Zwitterion around pH of the GIT.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound is associated with Disulfiram-like reaction?
explanation: Compound 2 (cefamandole) because R2- contains MTT ring.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound is NOT used with β-lactamase inhibitors?
explanation: Compound 3 (nafcillin) contains bulky R group directly attached to amide.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound shows the least amount of antimicrobial activity?
explanation: Compound 2 (clavulanic acid) β-lactamase inhibitor; no antimicrobial activity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound must be used in combination with cilastin?
explanation: Compound 2 (imipenem) is hydrolyzed by dehydropeptidase in the kidney to a nephrotoxic metabolite. Cilastin inhibits dehydropeptisdase.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: GM is experienced a life-threatening reaction from amoxicillin, which antibiotic is safe for this patient to use?
explanation: Compound 3 (aztreonam) because no cross-allergic reactions with other β-lactams.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: Which compound(s) are acid stable and can be taken orally?
explanation: Compound 1 (ceftriaxone) contains heterocyclic ring, which broadens spectrum and increases anti-pseudomonal activity.

title: Sulfonamides
name: Hover over the molecule to view SAR Requirements.

compoundHotspots.name: Amine
compoundHotspots.text: Amine is essential: Must be un-substituted, Must be para to the sulfonamide

compoundHotspots.name: Benzene Ring
compoundHotspots.text: Benzene ring is essential

compoundHotspots.name: Sulfonamide
compoundHotspots.text: Sulfonamide is essential: Must be un-ionized to cross bacterial cell membrane, Must be ionized to interact with DHPS active site, Mono-substitution allowed (EWG & heterocycle are favorable), Di-substitution abolishes activity, Must be para to the amine.

title: Trimethoprim
name: Hover over Trimethoprim to view characteristic parts.

compoundHotspots.text: First Characteristic part of Trimethoprim
Second Characteristic part of Trimethoprim

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: Addition of heterocycle to sulfonamide is favorable and decreases pH to optimal range.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: Amine essential for activity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of the two compounds has greatest antimicrobial activity?
explanation: The negative charge on the sulfonamide can be stabilized by resonance with the ring.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which is a prodrug?
explanation: Compound 1 (prontosil) Metabolized by reductases to give active form of sulfonamide.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which is the longest acting sulfonamide?
explanation: Compound 2 (sulfadoxine) Has a half life of 150 hours.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the correct answer
question: Which characteristics, at physiological pH, would provide the most effective sulfonamide?
explanation: Lipophilicity is needed to enter the cell and ionization is required to bind to enzyme.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Mechanism of Action
question: Which of the following inhibits DHPS?
explanation: Compound 1 is sulfamethoxazole.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Mechanism of Action
question: Which of the following inhibits DHFR?
explanation: Compound 1 is trimethoprim.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: KT has a history of Steven Johnson Syndrome, which antibiotic is best avoided in her?
explanation: Compound 3 (sulfamethoxazole) is a sulfonamide which can lead to this life-threatening rash.

title: Quinolones
name: Hover over the Quinolones compound to view SAR.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Position 1: Nitrogen can allow substitutions of alkyl (Me, Et, cPr) or aryl (2,4-difluorophenyl) groups

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Position 2: Can be either a carbon or nitrogen

compoundHotspots.name: Position 3
compoundHotspots.text: Position 3: Must be unsubstituted carboxylic acid

compoundHotspots.name: Position 4
compoundHotspots.text: Position 4: Must be ketone

compoundHotspots.name: Position 6
compoundHotspots.text: Position 6: Fluorine substitution increases activity and broadens spectrum

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: Position 7: Substitution with nitrogen containing heterocycles (piperazine ring) broadens spectrum; potential for zwitterion

compoundHotspots.name: Position 8
compoundHotspots.text: Position 8: Substitution with small polar groups (OCH3, F, Cl) increases activity

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: Ketone at position 4 is essential to bind to target.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: F at position 6 increases activity and broadens spectrum.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: Methoxy substitution at position 8 increases activity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which is the most active quinolone?
explanation: Moxifloxacin (compound 1) because the addition of methoxy at position 8 improves activity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: What does the addition of the circled group result in?
explanation: Because it increases activity against pseudomonas.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: What can the circled moities lead to?
explanation: Chelation with metals can reduce oral absorption; do not take with antacids, mineral supplements, or dairy products.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: JT is a 4-year-old boy diagnosed with a gram-negative infection, which antibiotic do you NOT recommend?
explanation: Ciprofloxacin (Compound 2) should be recommended since quinolones can lead to tendon rupture in young children and should never be used first line.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: AM is diagnosed with a pseudomonal infection, which antibiotic do you recommend?
explanation: Norfloxacin (Compound 2) contains piperazine ring, which gives it anti-pseudomonal activity.

title: Aminoglycosides
name: Hover over the Aminoglycosides compound to view SAR.

compoundHotspots.name: Ring 1
compoundHotspots.text: Ring 1: The amine can be methylated or changed to a hydroxyl group, but its removal will abolish activity.

compoundHotspots.name: Ring 2
compoundHotspots.text: Ring 2: Many modifications are possible, for example the 3- amine can be substituted or acylated.

compoundHotspots.name: Ring 3
compoundHotspots.text: Ring 3: -Crucial for broad-spectrum activity. -First target of inactivating enzymes. -The 2-, 3-, 4- hydroxyl groups are not essential for activity. -Methylation of the amine will retain activity and will lower susceptibility to transferases. -All substitutions must be equatorial

title: Tetracyclines
name: Hover over the Tetracyclines compound to view SAR.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 1
compoundHotspots.text: Positions 1, 10, 11, 12 and 12a: any changes will completely abolish activity, even changes in the stereochemical configuration.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 2
compoundHotspots.text: Position 2: Any changes leads to decreased activity, even substitution to the amide.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 4
compoundHotspots.text: Position 3: Amine in the α-position is essential, but monosubstitution is also active.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 5
compoundHotspots.text: Position 5: R4 can be a hydroxyl, keto group or a hydrogen, and all are active.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 6
compoundHotspots.text: Position 6: Both substitutions (R2 and R3) are not necessary.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 7
compoundHotspots.text: Position 7: Cl, F, Br, NO2 and a tertiary amine are all active.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 8
compoundHotspots.text: Position 8: Any electron withdrawing or donating group is still active

compoundHotspots.name: Position 9
compoundHotspots.text: Position 9: Bulky substitution decreases resistance.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 10
compoundHotspots.text: Positions 1, 10, 11, 12 and 12a: any changes will completely abolish activity, even changes in the stereochemical configuration.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 11
compoundHotspots.text: Positions 1, 10, 11, 12 and 12a: any changes will completely abolish activity, even changes in the stereochemical configuration.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 12
compoundHotspots.text: Positions 1, 10, 11, 12 and 12a: any changes will completely abolish activity, even changes in the stereochemical configuration.

compoundHotspots.name: Position 12a
compoundHotspots.text: Positions 1, 10, 11, 12 and 12a: any changes will completely abolish activity, even changes in the stereochemical configuration.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease chemical stability?
explanation: Replacement of OH with H at position 6 makes the compound more stable.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease bacterial resistance?
explanation: Addition of bulky group protects the compound from inactivating enzymes.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of the following binds to both the 30S and 50S ribosomal units?
explanation: Tobramycin (compound 2) is the only aminoglycoside that binds to both ribosomal units.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of the following is only used topically?
explanation: Neomycin (Compound 1) because only used topically due to nephrotoxicity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of the following does NOT bind to the 30S ribosomal unit?
explanation: Azithromycin (Compound 2) because Macrolides bind to the 50S ribosomal unit.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of the following is NOT bactericidal?
explanation: Tetracycline (Compound 2) because Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which is less susceptible to bacterial resistance?
explanation: Tigecycline (Compound 3) because addition of bulky group to position 9.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which antibiotic is used primarily by IV injections?
explanation: Gentamicin (Compound 3) because Aminoglycosides are not orally absorbed.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: What is the main advantage of the circled group?
explanation: Less spots for inactivating enzymes to act.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: What is the importance of retaining the stereochemistry of the circled group?
explanation: Essential for activity.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: Which reaction of this compound leads to a toxic product?
explanation: Nephrotoxic product.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: Which reactions inactivate this compound?
explanation: No explanation provided.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: Carly Sandbergin is going on vacation to sunny Florida, which antibiotic(s) should she avoid?
explanation: Doxycycline (Compound 1) & Ciprofloxacin (Compound 2) because both tetracyclines and quinolones can lead to phototoxicity.

title: Ketolides
name: Hover over the Ketolides compound to view SAR.

compoundHotspots.name: 3-keto functional group
compoundHotspots.text: 3-keto functional group replaces L-cladinose sugar of erythromycin A: Restores activity against bacteria with inducible resistance mediated by Erm, and enhances activity against streptococci with Mef-mediated macrolide efflux

compoundHotspots.name: Carbamate Side Chain
compoundHotspots.text: Carbamate Side Chain Addition: Promotes activity against both erythromycin-sensitive and erythromycin-resistant bacteria by introducing an interaction with domain II of the 23S rRNA.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease chemical stability?
explanation: Replacement of OH with OCH3 reduces acid-catalyzed degradation.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease acid stability?
explanation: 15 member ring (with no ketone) increases acid stability and permits accumulation of azithromycin in the cell.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Activity Change
question: Will the following change increase or decrease activity?
explanation: Cl increases lipophilicity and has better oral absorption.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which compound is less susceptible to bacteria resistance?
explanation: Telithromycin (Compound 1) because the addition of 3-keto group and carbamate side chain.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Compare Compounds
question: Which of the following is NOT bacteriostatic?
explanation: Gentamicin (Compound 1) because Aminoglycosides are bactericidal.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Choose the Correct Answer
question: Gray Baby Syndrome results from inability to produce which metabolite?
explanation: No explanation provided.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: Lucille Mangonzy is experiencing diarrhea after taking her antibiotic, which compound did she most likely take?
explanation: Clindamycin (Compound 3) has highest incidence of pseudomembranous colitis.

title: SAR Practice Problem
name: Clinical Case Study
question: Which compound is less susceptible to bacteria resistance?
explanation: Chloramphenicol (Compound 1) has a major toxicity of aplastic anemia.
